chapter.title: 41 Morganellaceae, Erwiniaceae, Hafniaceae, and Selected Enterobacterales

sect1.title: 41 Morganellaceae, Erwiniaceae, Hafniaceae, and Selected Enterobacterales

para.phrase: SAMANTHA R. GIFFEN AND KEVIN ALBY

sect1.para: The recent reclassification of the orderEnterobacteriales to Enterobacterales as well as the taxonomic shuffling of many members of the former family Enterobacteriaceae has increased the importance and awareness of a number of non-Enterobacteriaceae families. These include commonly known families, such as Morganellaceae, and lesser-known families, such as Budviciaceae. The focus of this chapter is the families Morganellaceae, Erwiniaceae, Hafniaceae, Budviciaceae, and Pectobacteriaceae. The reader is referred to other chapters of this Manual for other related organisms within the Enterobacterales.

Several taxonomic changes within theEnterobacterales have occurred since publication of the previous edition of this Manual, and there will continue to be taxonomic changes following additional analyses. Table 1 covers some of the organisms discussed in this chapter. In addition to the genera and species listed, there are others for which human cases have not been described. Some genera and species reported to be isolated only from nonhuman sources, such as insects, plants, fish, marine animals, or birds, may not be included in the tables or text of this chapter. As nomenclature changes over time, updates can be found at the LPSN (List of Prokaryotic Names with Standing in Nomenclature) website, http://www.bacterio.net/.

sect1.title: Morganellaceae
sect1.para: The family most commonly encountered in the clinical laboratory discussed in this chapter is likely the familyMorganellaceae. This family contains the familiar genera Proteus, Providencia, and Morganella, as well as the less common Arsenophonus, Cosenzaea, Moellerella, Photorhabdus, and Xenorhabdus. The genus Proteus comprises six species: Proteus mirabilis, P. vulgaris, P. penneri, P. hauseri, P. terrae, and P. cibarius (1, 2). P. mirabilis is the most commonly encountered species in this genus in clinical laboratories due to its standing as a common uropathogen (3). The genera Providencia and Morganella are closely related to Proteus, and many members (e.g., Providencia rettgeri, P. alcalifaciens, and Morganella morganii) are former Proteus spp. These organisms are found worldwide and are common components of human and animal gastrointestinal and environmental microbiotas. In a large, 6-year, population-based survey of Proteeae, 85% (4,290 of 5,047) of isolates were community acquired, although Providencia isolates were more likely to be acquired in nursing homes (4). Females (69%) and older individuals (median age, 70 years) were at the highest risk of infection, and the most common specimen sources were urine (86%), soft tissues (7%), blood (3%), miscellaneous fluids (2%), and the respiratory tract (2%). P. mirabilis, predominantly from urine, was the most frequently isolated species (77%). Non-P. mirabilis species (primarily P. vulgaris) were isolated from wounds and soft tissue more often than urine. Of the Providencia species, P. stuartii is isolated twice as often as other species. M. morganii is most frequently considered a health care-associated pathogen, primarily causing urinary tract infections, though wound infections and bacteremias are also commonly encountered. Respiratory infections are rare (5). Other genera in the family Morganellaceae include Arsenophonus, Cosenzaea, Moellerella, Photorhabdus, and Xenorhabdus. With the exception of Moellerella, these genera are composed largely of insect pathogens and endosymbionts (6). Occasionally, these organisms have been found in human infections, with Moellerella and Photorhabdus being the most frequently isolated. Moellerella wisconsensis has been found in multiple cases associated with cholecystitis (7, 8). Photorhabdus is composed of Photorhabdus luminescens, P. temperata, and P. asymbiotica. They are bioluminescent bacteria which are pathogenic to insects and endosymbionts of nematodes. Only P. asymbiotica has been found in human infections. Most commonly, P. asymbiotica infections are skin and soft tissue infections associated with exposure to sand or soil; however, some cases have progressed to dissemination and bacteremia (9). Although not recovered in culture, Arsenophonus species has been found in skin eschars associated with Orientia tsutsugamushi by PCR (10).

sect1.title: Erwiniaceae
sect1.para: The familyErwiniaceae contains many important plant-associated pathogens. Erwinia amylovora, for example, is responsible for blight disease that has disrupted commercial production of fruit such as apples and pears (11). Realization of phenotypic or genotypic similarities has led to the reclassification of many Erwinia spp. as Pantoea or Enterobacter species; Erwinia cancerogenus, Erwinia nimipressuralis, and Erwinia dissolvens have all been reclassified as Enterobacter (12). It is rare to find Erwinia species as clinical isolates, although a few cases have been reported (13–15).

table.title: TABLE 1 Nomenclature and sources of selected genera and species within Enterobacterales ord. nov.a

entry.phrase: P. agglomerans (Enterobacter agglomerans, Erwinia herbicola, Erwinia milletiae)
All sites; UT and feces common

sect1.para: aOrganisms included based on reports of isolation from human sources. CSF, cerebrospinal fluid; RT, respiratory tract; UT, urinary tract. Adapted from Table 1 in chapter 40 of the 12th edition of this Manual.

The genusPantoea historically included strains from the Erwinia herbicola-Enterobacter agglomerans complex and DNA groups I, II, IV, and V (16). The genus has undergone recent taxonomic changes, and it now includes about two dozen published species (17, 18) The application of multilocus sequence analysis (MLSA; four-locus scheme) had also aided in the naming of other Pantoea species, such as Pectobacterium cypripedii, which is now Pantoea cypripedii (19). In addition, Pantoea citrea, Pantoea punctata, and Pantoea terra have been transferred to the genus Tatumella (20). Phenotypic similarities and the close relatedness of Pantoea to other Enterobacterales have made it challenging to rapidly identify these organisms (21). Tatumella species produce 2-ketogluconate dehydrogenase, which is different from Pantoea species, making the two distinguishable with a biochemical test (20). Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) has played a critical role in distinguishing different Pantoea species, since commercial biochemical test kits are often not reliable (22).

Pantoea species have been isolated from plants, humans, and the natural environment, although they are most commonly plant pathogens. Pantoea species often produce a yellow pigment which is indicative of a virulence factor that provides antioxidant properties and UV light protection. There have been several recorded cases of Pantoea species causing human infections (18, 23). Pantoea agglomerans is the most frequently identified human pathogen, although there are recorded infections with other species, including P. brenneri, P. conspicua, P. eucrina, and P. septica (19). Some human infections are a result of trauma from penetration with an object contaminated with soil or plant matter, which results in soft tissue infection, septic arthritis, or osteomyelitis. On the other hand, health care-associated infections may result from contaminated intravenous or other administered fluids. There have been several reports of P. agglomerans infections in children. Many affected children have underlying conditions, and the infections are often polymicrobial, bringing the specific significance of Pantoea into question (18). P. ananatis was recovered from a case of a corneal ulcer associated with vegetable material (24). P. intestinalis has been found in human feces, although the significance of this finding remains unclear (19, 25). P. dispersa central line-associated bloodstream infections have been reported (26).

Other members of the familyErwiniaceae include Buchnera, Kalamiella, Mixta, Phaseolibacter, and Wigglesworthia. Kalamiella piersonii was found in association with a kidney stone (27). Mixta species were found in a thoracic infection in a neonate (28). Tatumella ptyseos has been reported to cause sepsis (29, 30) and was found in contaminated infant formula (31). Wigglesworthia is notable for being an endosymbiont of tsetse flies that can influence trypanosome transmission (32).

sect1.title: Hafniaceae
sect1.para: The genusHafnia, in the family Hafniaceae fam. nov., is composed of two species, Hafnia alvei and H. paralvei, that are biochemically (β-glucosidase, malonate, D-arabinose, salicin, and esculin) distinguishable; both have been recovered from clinical samples of varying significance (33). Although H. alvei isolates are more likely to be toxigenic than H. paralvei isolates, both species produce a Vero-cytolytic toxin. Other reported virulence characteristics include siderophores, resistance to complement-mediated lysis, and possession of type 1 and 3 fimbriae (34). Like most Enterobacterales, Hafnia species have been recovered from a variety of animals, predominantly from the gastrointestinal tract. Recovery is also associated with a variety of foods including meat, dairy, and honey (35).

Case series have debated whetherHafnia species are primarily community- or health care-acquired pathogens; a minority of cases involve significant infection (36). Isolates are recovered primarily from urine, respiratory, and gastrointestinal sources (37). They are typically found in those who are immunosuppressed or have significant comorbidities, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, malignancy, or abdominal surgery. Interestingly, while Hafnia species are frequently involved in polymicrobial infections, some significant infections have been monomicrobial, which is unusual among less commonly encountered Enterobacterales (36). Although surveillance studies involving Hafnia species are rare, there is a suggestion of increased risk of infection in women and older individuals (38).

The genusEdwardsiella, in the family Hafniaceae fam. nov., includes Edwardsiella tarda, E. ictaluri, E. piscicida, and E. hoshinae. These are primarily fish pathogens causing economic losses to aquaculture industries worldwide, with E. tarda causing >60% mortality among Asian eel populations (39). E. tarda is a broad-host-range pathogen that infects various species of fish and animals including humans. E. ictaluri is highly host adapted to channel catfish and is not of clinical concern. The ability of E. hoshinae to cause disease has not been established, and little is known regarding its habitat(s) (40). A systematic review of the literature examining 77 cases of E. tarda bacteremia demonstrated that it is associated with significant (45%) mortality (41). Common environmental risk factors for infection included factors associated with foodborne illness, summer and autumn periods, regions of Eastern Asia and the Gulf of Mexico, and exposure to brackish water or undercooked fish. Another significant finding was that a majority (66%) of cases involved people with underlying hepatobiliary disease. In addition to bacteremia, E. tarda can cause wound and gastrointestinal infections like those reported with Aeromonas species or Vibrio vulnificus (41). Preliminary genomic studies indicate that E. tarda can be split into two genotypes, with EdwGII strains being associated with human infections (42).

sect1.title: Other Selected Enterobacterales
sect1.para: The remaining families,Pectobacteriaceae and Budviciaceae, contain largely plant pathogens with limited clinical isolates. Acerihabitans, Biostraticola, Brenneria, Dickeya, Lonsdalea, Musicola, Pectobacterium, and Sodalis are all members of the Pectobacteriaceae, but none have been associated with human disease. Budvicia, Insectihabitans, Jinshanibacter, Leminorella, and Pragia are the members of the Budviciaceae, with Budvicia and Leminorella having been found in cases of human infection. Budvicia aquatica caused sepsis in an immunocompromised patient following exposure to water after Hurricane Katrina (43). A retrospective study found 18 cases of Leminorella associated with largely nosocomial infections in Israel (44). Leminorella grimontii was found in the blood in a fatal case of neonatal sepsis (45).

sect1.title: Plesiomonas
sect1.para: Given the phenotypic and genomic differences ofPlesiomonas species with other members of the Enterobacterales, it is not assigned to a family and is considered family incertae sedis, indicating an undefined relationship (46). Plesiomonas shigelloides is the only species in the genus Plesiomonas and the only oxidase-positive member of the Enterobacterales (47). The name Plesiomonas initially indicated a close association with Aeromonas; however, Aeromonas has been reclassified as a family within a different order. Analysis via several methods, including 5S rRNA gene analysis, 16S rRNA gene analysis, and multilocus sequence typing (MLST), as well as determining composition of lipopolysaccharide including lipid A structures, were used previously to group Plesiomonas with various members of the Enterobacterales (48). The natural environment of Plesiomonas species is fresh water or brackish waters with lower salinity, and it can be isolated from a variety of vertebrate hosts, although it can be difficult to distinguish colonization from infection (48). A major risk factor for development of P. shigelloides gastroenteritis is consumption of uncooked shellfish, with a stronger association with oysters than shrimp. A second risk factor is foreign travel, particularly to Japan and China, with travel to Mexico or the Caribbean also being a risk factor. A final association is a compromised immune system, particularly those with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), who have a 3-fold-higher risk than other populations (48). The pathogenicity of P. shigelloides is poorly understood. There are reports of toxins being secreted in vitro, including cholera-like toxin, thermostable and thermolabile toxins, β-hemolysins, and cytotoxin complex (49, 50). The somatic antigen may also play a role in pathogenicity, because the gene encoding the most common type, O17, shares almost complete identity with the form 1 (smooth) antigen gene of Shigella sonnei (51).

Although relatively rare, extraintestinal infections include bacteremia, meningitis, and wound infections. Many bacteremic patients have some type of gastrointestinal injury or dysfunction that may predispose them to infection. Wound infections are typically associated with injuries during activities involving water (48). Infections in neonates are suggested to arise from vertical transmission during birth, with several cases observed in babies born to mothers who had diarrhea (52).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: In general, the less commonEnterobacterales are readily cultivated in the laboratory using the techniques used for more common organisms. The reader is referred to other chapters in this Manual for best practices on specimen collection, transport, and culturing. Many of these organisms, with the possible exception of Plesiomonas species, are stable for weeks at ambient temperatures on slants and for years at −70°C.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Many of the organisms in this chapter that are associated with infection are readily grown and isolated in the clinical laboratory. Some organisms, such asProteus species, have distinct phenotypes on some media, which are described below. The use of specialized media may be necessary when sampling environmental or other nonsterile sites to cultivate the organisms. The use of selective media can prevent swarming of Proteus species, which can aid in recovery of multiple organisms from mixed infections.

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: Except for theMorganellaceae, these organisms may be misidentified using commercial phenotypic and biochemical methods. Proteomic methods such as MALDI-TOF MS are largely accurate if the organism is included in the database. Many of the Morganellaceae and Hafniaceae and Plesiomonas are in the current FDA-cleared versions of MALDI-TOF MS databases in the United States (VITEK MS v3.2; Biotyper CA reference library). Additionally, many of the other organisms discussed in this chapter, including members of the Erwiniaceae, are present in the databases but have not been cleared by the FDA, so the manufacturers cannot claim the accuracy of these identifications. Therefore, additional testing, including 16S rRNA sequencing or whole-genome sequencing, may be necessary for definitive identification.

Gram-negative, oxidase-negative organisms that swarm on blood agar and form colonies that appear flat with tapered edges on MacConkey agar may be reported asProteus species. Spot indole-negative and ampicillin-susceptible strains may be reported as P. mirabilis, with spot indole-positive, ampicillin-resistant strains reported as P. vulgaris (53). P. hauseri, previously a subgroup of P. vulgaris, can be differentiated from P. vulgaris by negative salicin/esculin and trehalose reactions (53). Proteus organisms that do not fit the above-listed criteria must be fully identified by commercial or conventional biochemical methods or MALDI-TOF MS (53). Proteus species are identified with 95 to 100% accuracy by commercial biochemical systems, but Providencia identification rates vary from 79 to 100% (53). When Providencia species are misidentified, they are usually called Morganella or Proteus species. Urea-positive P. stuartii may be misidentified as P. rettgeri, or the system may suggest the use of specific additional tests for identification. Rapid phenotypic identification methods misidentify M. morganii subsp. morganii about 66% of the time. However, automated phenotypic identification methods, such as the VITEK 2 (bioMérieux, Marcy-l’Étoile, France) and MALDI-TOF MS platforms, perform well for species-level identifications of these organisms (54, 55). Typical biochemical reactions of these organisms can be found in Table 2.

table.title: TABLE 2 Biochemical characterization of members of the genera Proteus, Providencia, and Morganellaa

Genetic heterogeneity in the genusPantoea may make it challenging for commercial phenotypic identification systems used in clinical laboratories (56). Pantoea agglomerans has classically been difficult to identify by commercial systems but is distinguishable from similar species by a negative indole test, a yellow pigment, and being lysine, arginine, and ornithine negative (57, 58). Most Pantoea species are indole negative, except for P. ananatis and P. stewartii subsp. indologenes (59). For laboratories without access to MALDI-TOF MS, it may be advisable to send suspected Pantoea samples to a reference laboratory for confirmation, since biochemical tests may not be sufficient for confirmatory identification. Table 3 provides biochemical reactions for some less commonly encountered Enterobacterales. Erwinia species are not included in some commercially available biochemical clinical identification systems, and previously classified Pantoea or Enterobacter may be more likely to be identified as Erwinia in clinical laboratories using mass spectrometry and genetic analysis (60).

Hafnia species have biochemical reactions similar to those of other Enterobacterales, in particular Enterobacter and Serratia species. Reactions that are most helpful in identifying Hafnia are malonate, salicin, β-glucosidase and D-arabinose (33). Additional reactions can be found in Table 4. Importantly, MALDI-TOF MS is largely reliable for the identification of Hafnia species, with the closely related Obesumbacterium being the most likely misidentification (61). Leminorella can be identified by tyrosine hydrolysis, hydrogen sulfide production, and L-arabinose fermentation while not fermenting D-mannose (44). Differentiation of some hydrogen sulfide-producing bacteria is found in Table 5.

Plesiomonas produces non-lactose-, non-sucrose-fermenting colonies on enteric plating media. It does not grow on thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose medium, but on cefsulodin-irgasan-novobiocin medium, opaque colonies without a pink center (mannitol not fermented) are suspicious for plesiomonads. Two other oxidase-positive organisms, Pseudomonas and Aeromonas species, grow on cefsulodin-irgasan-novobiocin as well, although Aeromonas colonies have a pink center with an opaque apron. Inositol fermentation and a positive reaction in Moeller’s lysine, arginine, and ornithine tests differentiate Plesiomonas species from these agents as well as other organisms.

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Amplification Testing
sect1.para: While stand-alone nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is uncommon for detection ofEnterobacterales in clinical specimens, syndromic panel testing by nucleic acid amplification has allowed for the rapid progression of clinical microbiology diagnostics. There are several FDA-cleared panels available for a variety of clinical presentations, including positive blood cultures, pneumonia, and gastrointestinal infections. These panels include a variety of relevant microbiological targets depending on what the common causative organisms are for the given infection. With regard to the organisms discussed in this chapter, all three (GenMark, BioFire, and Luminex) currently FDA-cleared molecular syndromic panels for positive blood cultures include identification of Proteus species to the genus level. Additionally, the Accelerate phenotypic panel includes Proteus species among its fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) targets. The GenMark panel also includes Morganella morganii and specific identification of Proteus mirabilis (62). It is important to note that there have been instances where clinical laboratories detected unrecoverable Proteus species DNA in blood culture bottles, including uninoculated bottles (62). Two pneumonia syndromic panels are currently FDA cleared and are produced by BioFire and Curetis. Both panels detect Proteus species, while the Curetis panel additionally detects Morganella morganii. Of the gastrointestinal panels available, only panels from BioFire and Becton Dickinson currently detect Plesiomonas shigelloides (62).

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: The broad organisms of the orderEnterobacterales are reflected not only in its phenotypic diversity but in its genomic diversity as well. Classical 16S rRNA-based phylogeny has poor resolution among members of the order, so additional genes are frequently used in MLSA or MLST schemes. Commonly used targets include recA, infB, gyrB, rpoB, and atpD, among others (46). While potentially useful for small-scale relatedness, these approaches lack the resolution for large-scale comparisons among large groups of diverse organisms. Fortunately, the availability of whole-genome sequencing has allowed for rapid improvements in typing and relatedness, as members of the Enterobacterales are among the most common publicly available genomes with thousands of entries. For example, the Erwiniaceae have over 1,000 genomes and the Morganellaceae have over 2,000 genomes available at NCBI (63). With this level of data available, typing tools are more about the bioinformatics used for comparison than the genomic data.

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITY
sect2.para: TheMorganellaceae are the most familiar organisms for which antimicrobial susceptibility testing is routinely performed. Most commercial systems can readily detect resistance in these organisms and have only rare limitations for antimicrobial susceptibility reporting. A Turkish study found that while the overall incidence of P. agglomerans infection was low, this organism demonstrated the same ability to develop significant antimicrobial resistance, including carbapenem resistance, as other Enterobacterales (64). The same is true in general for the Erwiniaceae and Hafniaceae. For other uncommon Enterobacterales, commercial systems may or may not be able to interpret the AST data, as many systems require an identification before reporting. Reference methods such as broth microdilution and disk diffusion testing can still be performed and interpreted in accordance with the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) and/or European Committee on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (EUCAST) guidance for Enterobacterales provided that the organism exhibits adequate growth under test conditions. For example, isolates of P. mirabilis are intrinsically resistant to nitrofurantoin, the tetracyclines, and colistin but are generally susceptible to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, the penicillins, cephalosporins, and aminoglycosides (65). Although most strains are susceptible to ciprofloxacin, resistance occurs with unrestricted use of the antibiotic (66). P. penneri and P. vulgaris have resistance profiles similar to those of Morganella species; they are susceptible to broad-spectrum cephalosporins, cefoxitin, cefepime, aztreonam, and the aminoglycosides and are intrinsically resistant to amoxicillin, ampicillin, cefazolin, cefuroxime, and nitrofurantoin, among other antimicrobials. P. rettgeri and P. stuartii are resistant to gentamicin and tobramycin but susceptible to amikacin. Urine isolates are susceptible to broad- and expanded-spectrum cephalosporins, ciprofloxacin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Many of theEnterobacterales discussed in this chapter are intrinsically resistant to polymyxins, including colistin, in vitro. This includes members of Proteus, Providencia, and Morganella, along with the less commonly encountered Hafnia and Edwardsiella (37, 67). Interestingly a strain of Mixta calida was found to harbor an mcr-9-containing plasmid while remaining phenotypically susceptible. The authors hypothesized that this is due to a lack of necessary accessory genes in the organism. They pose the concern that this organism, among others, may be capable of harboring and transmitting mcr-9 (68).

Like otherEnterobacterales, organisms from nearly all these families have been found to harbor a variety of β-lactamase genes, including those for extended-spectrum β-lactamases (ESBLs), such as blaCTX-M. However, outside Proteus mirabilis, phenotypic testing for ESBL production is generally not performed. For additional information on the detection of ESBLs, the reader is referred to chapter 77. Some genera, such as Providencia, Morganella, and Proteus, have species that carry chromosomal ampC β-lactamase genes. These organisms have lower rates of mutations that cause derepression of the AmpC than Enterobacter species (69). Hafnia species also carry chromosomal AmpC and have rates of derepression mutations similar to those of Enterobacter species (69). Historical references to AmpC-harboring organisms are inaccurate with regard to current taxonomy. For example, included as part of the SPICE organism list (Serratia, Pseudomonas, indole-positive Proteus, Citrobacter, and Enterobacter), currently recognized indole-positive Proteus species such as P. vulgaris or P. penneri do not commonly harbor chromosomal AmpC beta-lactamases. This is different from when Providencia rettgeri and Morganella morganii were considered Proteus species (P. rettgeri and P. morganii, respectively) (70). Another example is that while Pantoea are commonly intermingled with Enterobacter species in terms of phenotypic identification and many were formerly Enterobacter species, they may not actually carry chromosomal ampC and may not need to be treated like Enterobacter species in terms of antimicrobial susceptibility reporting (e.g., suppressing susceptible results of third-generation cephalosporins).

Similarly, many of the organisms described in this chapter have also been found to have carbapenemases, including both common serine (KPC) enzymes and metalloenzymes (NDM enzymes). Notably, organisms that have derepression of AmpC can develop carbapenem resistance in the presence of porin alterations or changes in efflux pumps. Importantly, organisms such asProteus, Providencia, and Morganella species may display elevated imipenem MICs but by mechanisms other than carbapenemase production, such as altered penicillin-binding proteins (71).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Some organisms, such asProteus, Providencia, and Morganella species, have been readily identified and reported by the microbiology laboratory for a number of years. Our experience tells us what typical sources of isolation are, what the organisms look like on media (e.g., swarming Proteus), and what common antimicrobial resistance patterns are (e.g., intrinsic resistance to nitrofurantoin and tetracyclines). Other organisms, such as Pantoea species, have been known to the laboratory, most notably based on their yellow pigmentation, but their makeup has changed. Organisms such as Hafnia, Erwinia, and Edwardsiella species have been readily identified only since the adoption of MALDI-TOF MS and may be considered emerging pathogens when, in fact, it is the better tools that are increasing their frequency of identification. Additional experience with these organisms will enable laboratorians to develop the familiarity they have with other Enterobacterales. Still others are not well represented in databases and require targeted or even whole-genome sequencing to readily identify them in the laboratory. Updates to MALDI-TOF MS databases and curation of 16S rRNA sequences will continue to allow the clinical microbiology to recognize and specifically identify generic Enterobacterales organism beyond oxidase and glucose fermentation.
